So, update on that trucker story I shared last night
There's a pretty good response on a video covering the various news outlet's stories on the matter

"There were a number of errors that he made involving the road conditions his speed his apparent unwillingness or lack of knowledge about the cut off‘s. The big problem is a company took a guy who barely knew what he was doing thrown behind the wheel in

in the mountains in bad conditions.

I’ve been a driver for 25 years I’ve been a trainer. This should not have happened but putting this much blame on him and not the company is creating a situation where they will push people to do things they shouldn’t
be doing and get away with it."
So the guy who got 110 years for an accident?  Was he at fault for the accident?  Yes.  Was it completely his fault? No.
Brake failure.  Company with multiple violations on inspections in the past several years.  And to top it all off, they through at utter newb into the gauntlet.
At this point the company needs to be held responsible :|
Oh crumbs. Well, that is correct, I must admit...a symptom of a larger problem...

yeah, noodle, so many industries are slimming down the concept of operating to train as being a goal of the organization to being “ah ya cleared the CDL, that equals the same thing as 30 years experience, right?”
“you’re hired at 1/3rd the rate of the senior guy leaving! it’s win-win!”
“psst meanwhile you're also inheriting his what should be assigned his expert-only route”
the old guard is retiring taking primo benefits and awesome pay - plus a more well thought out approach - and new business strategy is driving these “modern” (bleugh) decisions
in the famous Pink Floyd lyrics... “Sit down dear boy, have a cigar, you’re gonna go far~ you’ll fly high, never gonna die- they’re gonna LOVE you...“
“...the band is really just fantastic, that’s REALLY what I think ...by the way? ...which one’s Pink?”

I think we're gonna definitely see a lot more of this in the close future. Truckers are already losing their jobs to scabs for asking to unionize these past couple years. And I think self driving trucks is gonna make it even more apparent that companies

My prediction is that the AI trucks are gonna have bare minimum paid "monitors" driving the trucks in case of emergencies. And those monitors are gonna be the ones to take the fall for everything that happens.

While I hate to break us away from the more pleasant conversation, I feel like I'll continue where Dadro left off

When these well-paying middle class trucking jobs are all but annihilated due to self-driving trucks, the government is still probably going to blow smoke up their own ass about new jobs being made and unemployment being low.
Completely ignoring the fact that unemployment is arguably the most meaningless employment metric ever conceived, because it ignores so much of the larger picture.
Such as people just opting out of work because it's either government benefits or some shitty paying customer service job when so many customers in America are entitle pricks
Or the fact that people are working 2 - 3 jobs and still just *barely* scraping by, while having 0 ability to save / invest.
Or that most of the new jobs being made are in the customer service sector.

But it's fine, no need to change CEO's and executives giving themselves tens to hundreds of millions in bonuses every year while simultaneously laying off hundreds to thousands of employees on record years
Or companies cheaping out on construction and weather safety for a, say, giant effing warehouse built smack dab in tornado alley that just partially collapsed and killed 6?

yeah, it's because the reward system and definition of doing a 'good job' and achieving 'success' becomes more and more skewed toward the bottom line and not the product/job satisfaction higher up the ladder you go
it used to be enough that all pulling the same direction toward making a good product = a good business
it's not quite that simple anymore

Oh, a "Good" business is still very much possible. Look at Costco. But the goal isn't a "Good" business. It's "Make a business that pulls in ALL of the money ALL of the time for infinitely increasing returns for the investors"
